He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if itâ€™s just a polite acknowledgment or a â€œyesâ€ or â€œno,â€ would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and Iâ€™m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, Iâ€™m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if itâ€™s just a polite acknowledgment or a â€œyesâ€ or â€œno,â€ would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and Iâ€™m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, Iâ€™m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if itâ€™s just a polite acknowledgment or a â€œyesâ€ or â€œno,â€ would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and Iâ€™m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, Iâ€™m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if itâ€™s just a polite acknowledgment or a â€œyesâ€ or â€œno,â€ would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and Iâ€™m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, Iâ€™m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if itâ€™s just a polite acknowledgment or a â€œyesâ€ or â€œno,â€ would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and Iâ€™m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. Iâ€™ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. Iâ€™ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. Iâ€™ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, Iâ€™m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. Iâ€™m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) â§ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.â†’ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.â†’ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.â†’ Didnâ€™t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.â†’ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didnâ€™t stop.--Also, If youâ€™re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--â§ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)â†’ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.â†’ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.â†’ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as â€œbonus timeâ€ for deep focus.â§ Didnâ€™t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)â†’ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1â€“1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.â†’ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by â€œrecent jobsâ€), and company career pages directly.â†’ Kept Naukri profile â€œactiveâ€ by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.â†’ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used â€œactively hiringâ€ filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).â§ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Workedâ†’ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.â†’ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: â€œHereâ€™s my background, hereâ€™s the job, hereâ€™s why I fit.â€â†’ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.â§ Resume: Only What Matters, No â€œGyaanâ€â†’ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just â€œNetflix Cloneâ€. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.â†’ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (â€œimproved speed by X%â€), not just feature lists.â†’ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments â†¡
